title: Currency-rigging lawsuit settlements rise past $2 bln -lawyer
text:
(Adds details on settlement, background on litigation) 
By Nate Raymond 
NEW YORK, Aug 13 (Reuters) - Investors have recovered more than $2 billion in settlements with nine banks over claims of price-rigging in the foreign exchange market, and are continuing to pursue claims against seven other banks, a lawyer for the plaintiffs said Thursday. 
HSBC Holdings Plc (HKSE: 0005.HK - news ) , Barclays Plc (LSE: BARC.L - news ) , BNP (Paris: FR0000131104 - news ) Paribas SA and Goldman Sachs Group Inc are among the latest banks to reach settlement in the class action litigation, Christopher Burke, the lawyer, said in federal court in Manhattan (Hamburg: 32U.HM - news ) . 
Those banks and five others have agreed to provide "substantial cooperation" as the plaintiffs pursue claims against seven other defendants accused of manipulating prices in the $5.4 trillion-per-day foreign exchange market, Burke said. 
"We look forward if necessary to litigating through trial," Burke said in an interview after the hearing. 
He declined to say much each bank would pay. Goldman Sachs (NYSE: GS-PB - news ) has agreed to pay $129.5 million, a person familiar with the matter said. 
The Wall Street Journal in June reported that HSBC would pay $285 million while Barclays would pay $375 million. Those numbers remain unconfirmed, and the banks on Thursday either declined comment or did not respond to a request for comment. 
The plaintiffs previously announced $808.5 million settlements with four banks, while Royal Bank of Scotland Group Plc in May disclosed it had reached a deal without announcing the terms. 
Investors including hedge funds and pension funds accused the banks of having impeded competition by conspiring to manipulate the fix in chat rooms, instant messages and emails. 
As part of the scheme, the plaintiffs said, traders at the banks from 2003 through 2013 used chat rooms with names such as "The Cartel," "The Bandits' Club," and "The Mafia" to communicate with each other 
They said traders manipulated prices through tactics such as "front running," "banging the close" and "painting the screen," using disguised names to swap confidential orders. 
The class action settlements came after four of the banks -Citigroup Inc (NYSE: C - news ) , JPMorgan Chase & Co (Xetra: 850628 - news ) , Barclays and RBS (LSE: RBS.L - news ) - pleaded guilty in May to fraud charges for trying to manipulate foreign exchange rates. 
In total, U.S (Other OTC: UBGXF - news ) . and European regulators so far have extracted more than $10 billion in settlements with seven banks over the alleged manipulation schemes. 
In the class action, previously announced settlements include $99.5 million from JPMorgan (LSE: JPIU.L - news ) , $394 million from Citigroup, $180 million from Bank of America Corp and $135 million from UBS AG (NYSEArca: FBGX - news ) . 
The case is In re: Foreign Exchange Benchmark Rates Antitrust Litigation, U.S. District Court, Southern District of New York, No. 13-07789. (Reporting by Nate Raymond in New York; Editing by David Gregorio and Leslie Adler)
